idCitation.resTitle: Mapping of Massachusetts Coastal Tidal Flats

dataIdInfo.idAbs: This tidal flat dataset is taken from the MA Department of Environmental Protection's update of its statewide wetlands mapping program which has been mapping wetlands using aerial photography since 1990 (http://www.mass.gov/anf/research-and-tech/it-serv-and-support/application-serv/office-of-geographic-information-massgis/datalayers/depwetlands112000.html). The source aerial digital imagery for this update was flown in spring 2005 during non-tide specified times at a resolution of 0.5 m. Additionally, collateral digital low tide imagery at resolution of 0.4 m, flown during the spring/summer of the period 2006-2010 for the purpose of eelgrass mapping was utilized as necessary. The interpretation of this imagery was analyzed by MA DEP staff in stereo utilizing the Esri ArcGIS software equipped with the PurView stereo viewing tool. Due to the scale of the imagery and the availability of low tide collateral imagery, minimal field-checking was conducted on this 2005 update.
dataIdInfo.idPurp: The purpose of the MA Wetlands Mapping Program is to provide accurate current mapping information of the state's wetlands down to a minimum mapping unit of 0.25 m. The original mapping program, started in 1990, utilized aerial photography and extensive ground-truthing fieldwork. That highly-utilized dataset has been updated using newer digital imagery of much higher resolution. This tidal flat dataset has been further improved with the availability of current low tide-specific imagery.

overview.eaover: Tidal Flats (TF) "Tidal Flats" refers to the nearly level part of a Coastal Beach that extends from the mean low water (MLW) line landward to the more steeply sloping face of the Coastal Beach. Tidal Flats may also be present adjacent to Salt Marshes or as isolated areas surrounded by open water. For the purposes of this mapping effort, Tidal Flats will be delineated separately from Coastal Beach (BE) only when they are nearly level landforms located on the protected side of a coastal beach or coastal barrier, or within a bay. The sediment will generally be finer grained sand or mud. Those intertidal portions of Coastal Beach that are located along a high-energy coastline exposed directly to ocean influence will remain included within the Coastal Beach (BE) type. Only Tidal Flats that are regularly exposed at MLW will be mapped as TF. Irregularly exposed tidal flats will be classified as Open Water (OW). In many cases, aerial photography will not show mean low water conditions, making accurate delineation of Tidal Flats difficult. The PI should map the Tidal Flats to the extent of the signature visible on the aerial photo. It is understood that because the aerial photos represent only one moment in time, and are not specifically taken at low tide, the TFs mapped are only a subset of the full extent of Tidal Flats that exist in any particular area. The extent of particular Tidal Flats may also be dynamic, changing from one year to the next due to changing patterns and volumes of sedimentation in various areas along the coast. The PI may rely on collateral data such as USGS maps, NOAA charts, or other recent photography taken at low tide to help determine the shape and extent of the Tidal Flat delineation. An effort should be made during field work to verify the accuracy of the extent of Tidal Flats shown on the aerial photo or described in the collateral data. In cases of conflicting information, a site visit at low tide is required.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.
